page.title: Morphology
page.subtitle: Detailed anatomy of the Kava plant with special focus on the economically significant root system.

intro.paragraph1: The morphology of Piper methysticum is the result of millennia of selection. While the above-ground parts of the plant are important for cultivar identification, the true value lies in the underground structures – the complex root system that contains the coveted kavalactones.

overview.title: Morphological Overview
overview.paragraph1: Kava is a perennial, evergreen shrub with a typical growth height of 1.5 to 3 meters. Under optimal conditions – abundant water, nutrients, and shade – individual plants can reach up to 5 meters.

rootSystem.title: The Root System
rootSystem.paragraph1: The economically and pharmacologically most important part of the Kava plant is the underground root system. It consists of two main components that differ in their composition and quality.

qualityAlert.title: Quality Feature:
qualityAlert.text: High-quality Kava is made exclusively from the roots. The use of above-ground plant parts (stems, leaves) is considered inferior and can lead to unwanted side effects.

stump.title: The Stump (Corm/Stump)
stump.paragraph1: The stump is the thick, woody part directly below the soil surface. It forms the central mass of the rootstock and can reach considerable dimensions in older plants.

properties.title: Properties
items: Color: Light brown to dark brown

lateralRoots.title: The Lateral Roots (Lateral Roots / Waka)
lateralRoots.paragraph1: The lateral roots are the finer roots that extend from the stump and spread through the soil. In Fiji, they are called "Waka" and are considered the highest quality component.

kavalactoneProfile.title: Kavalactone Profile
items: Total content: Highest of all plant parts

distribution.title: Kavalactone Distribution in the Plant
distribution.paragraph1: The concentration of kavalactones varies greatly between different plant parts. This has direct implications for the quality and safety of Kava products.

warningAlert.title: Warning:
warningAlert.text: The use of leaves and above-ground stem parts has been linked to historical reports of liver toxicity. High-quality Kava uses exclusively root material.

stems.title: Stems & Nodes
stems.paragraph1: The stems (trunks) of Kava are one of the most important features for cultivar identification. They grow upright and branch as they age.

structure.title: Structure
items: Nodes: Clearly visible thickenings, similar to bamboo
Internodes: The sections between nodes, variable in length
Diameter: 2-5 cm, depending on age and variety
Height: 1.5-3 m (up to 5 m under optimal conditions)

varietyFeatures.title: Variety Features
varietyFeatures.paragraph1: The color and pattern of the stems is a key feature for distinguishing cultivars:
items: Dark purple/Black: Rare, often particularly prized varieties

leaves.title: Leaves
leaves.paragraph1: Kava leaves are large, prominent, and serve primarily for photosynthesis. They are traditionally not used for Kava preparation.

flowers.title: Flowers & Fruits
flowers.paragraph1: Although Piper methysticum produces flowers, the plant is functionally sterile and does not form viable seeds.

sterility.title: Sterility
sterility.paragraph1: The sterility of P. methysticum is a consequence of high polyploidy (decaploidy). This means:

flowers.paragraph2: This sterility has far-reaching consequences: Without continuous human cultivation, Piper methysticum would become extinct within a generation. Every Kava plant existing today is the result of an unbroken chain of cutting propagation dating back to the first domestications about 3,000 years ago.
